hypothesis_content.title: Contrarian Fade of Panic-Headline Rallies
hypothesis_content.statement: A sharp intraday price spike (>4% in 2 hours) on high volume (>150% of 20-day average) that is directly attributed in news/social sentiment analysis to a 'panic' or 'FUD' event (e.g., exchange rumors, regulatory threats) will be partially retraced within 24 hours. Fading this spike by shorting at the peak provides a positive expectancy.
hypothesis_content.rationale: Panic-driven rallies are often fueled by short covering and emotional buying, not sustainable organic demand. They tend to exhaust quickly as the initial fear subsides and profit-taking occurs. The high volume confirms the emotional participation, making the move prone to reversal.
entry_conditions: BTC 2-hour candle closes >4% above previous 2-hour close
Real-time news/sentiment aggregator (e.g., TheTIE, Santiment) shows >60% of headline sentiment for the spike is tagged as 'Fear', 'FUD', or 'Negative'
Enter short at the open of the next 2-hour candle after the spike candle closes

exit_conditions.take_profit: Retracement of 50% of the initial 2-hour spike's price move
exit_conditions.stop_loss: Price moves 1.5x the initial spike magnitude above the entry price (i.e., continue up another 6% from entry)

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: The 50% retracement target is hit in less than 50% of trade instances within the 24-hour window. The average trade result is negative. The stop-loss is hit more frequently than the take-profit.
